questions.text: You are examining the nails of a patient with psoriasis. Which among the following nail findings is pathognomonic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Image 3 shows the oil drop sign/ salmon patches, which is a specific pathognomonic sign seen in psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin, characterized by red, scaly, sharply demarcated, indurated plaques usually seen on the extensor surfaces and scalp. It can affect any part of the nail unit, including the nail bed, nail matrix, and hyponychium. Nail changes in psoriasis are seen commonly. Various nail dystrophies that are seen in psoriasis-

  • Nail matrix disease presents as pits (most common), ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. 
  • Nail bed disease presents as subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter haemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with fever, pain, and refusal to use his right lower limb. He has a history of a recent ear infection. His WBC count was 22,000/ cumm with neutrophil predominance. ESR and CRP were elevated. The MRI demonstrated inflammatory changes in the bone marrow of the proximal tibia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis and the next best step of management would be to start empirical antibiotic therapy.

Acute osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone that usually occurs in children. The most common organism responsible is Staphylococcus aureus. 

Children with acute osteomyelitis present with pain, malaise, fever, and refusal to use the affected limb. There may often be a history of recent infection. On examination, the child is ill, with tachycardia, with fever. There is tenderness near the affected joint, with redness, swelling, warmth, and edema.

Clinical diagnosis is confirmed by aspirating pus or fluid from the abscess, soft tissues, or the adjacent joint. Investigations reveal elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. Blood cultures should be done if a fever >38 °C is detected.

MRI is helpful when the diagnosis is doubtful or when there is a suspected infection of the axial skeleton. It is sensitive even in the early phases of bone infections and detects bone marrow inflammation.

If osteomyelitis is suspected clinically, blood and fluid samples should be taken for laboratory investigations and treatment should be started immediately. There is no need to wait for confirmation of the diagnosis to start treatment. The main aspects of treatment include:

  • Antibiotics- initially empirical, then specific
  • Surgical drainage
  • Limb splinting and rest
  • Management of pain and dehydration

Children between 6 months and 6 years should be started on iv flucloxacillin and cefotaxime or cefuroxime. If antibiotics are started within the first 48 hours, drainage is not always needed. Surgical drainage is indicated when:

  • The patient does not respond to antibiotics
  • Signs such as swelling, edema, and fluctuation are present
  • Pus is aspirated

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of diarrhea for the past 3 days. On examination, he is tachypneic. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
pH 7.2
pCO2 20 mmHg
HCO3- 7 mEq/L
Cl- 120 mEq/L
Na+ 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. The normal pH is 7.35-7.45. 

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is >12 mEq/L. It occurs in conditions such as methanol poisoning, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, paracetamol poisoning, lactic acidosis, salicylate poisoning, etc. 

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH. 

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A young woman reported palpitations, dizziness, and sweating while getting ready for an office seminar. She recalls having experienced similar episodes in the past. She also reports having feelings of impending doom during these episodes. There is no history of medical illness or substance abuse. Which of the following is not useful in the treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic disorder. Flumazenil is not useful in the treatment of this condition and may even act as a panic-inducing substance (panicogen).

Panic disorder refers to an acute intense attack of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Such attacks may not only occur in response to a fearful situation, or phobic objects, or in response to obsession or separation as in other anxiety disorders.

There is a dysfunction in major neurotransmitter systems like norepinephrine, serotonin, and GABA. Panic-inducing substances or panicogens may induce such attacks and include substances like 5-35% carbon dioxide, sodium lactate, bicarbonate, yohimbine (α blocker), flumazenil (GABA antagonist), cholecystokinin and caffeine.

This disorder is characterised by the presence of an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes. During the episode, the person may experience symptoms like palpitations, sweating, trembling or shaking, shortness of breath, nausea, dizziness, chest pain or discomfort or fear of dying. The patient also might feel like losing control, having a heart attack, or going crazy. 

It is not attributable to any drug abuse, medication, medical condition or mental disorder.

Treatment of this condition can be done by cognitive behavioural therapy and drugs like benzodiazepines (alprazolam, lorazepam), selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (paroxetine), tricyclic antidepressants and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Panic disorder

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

1.Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:

  • Palpitation
  • Sweating
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Shortness of breath of smothering sensation
  • Choking sensation
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Chills or heat sensation
  • Paraesthesia’s
  • Derealisation or depersonalisation
  • Fear of losing control or “going crazy”
  • Fear of dying  

 2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

  • Immediate: benzodiazepines 
  • Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy

questions.text:
A biochemistry resident plots a graph while studying the effect of an inhibitor on an enzymatic reaction. Which of the following statements is false, with respect to the following graph that he has plotted?

Km: The substrate concentration at which velocity is half the maximum.

Vmax: The maximum velocity of a reaction.

v0: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration

choices.text: Reaction is with a non-competitive inhibitor
Inhibitor binds to the enzyme in location other than the active site
The degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of inhibitor
Can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The given graph represents a reaction with a non-competitive inhibitor and it cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

In contrast to competitive inhibitors, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations away from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of the inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high substrate concentration, non-competitive inhibition is irreversible and cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition. The biopsy on the frozen section is given below. Which of the following mutations is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient from a hilly (iodine deficient) area and the biopsy specimen showing capsular invasion by tumor follicles confirms the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma. It is associated with RAS mutation.

Follicular carcinomas are associated with acquired mutations that activate RAS or the PI­3K/AKT arm of the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (PIK3CA gene).

PAX8-PPARG fusion gene has been described in one-third to one-half of follicular carcinomas.

Note: TSHR and GNAS mutations are rare in follicular carcinomas; thus, toxic adenomas and toxic multinodular goiter do not seem to be forerunners of malignancy.

RET and GNAS mutations are associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. Below is its histopathology image showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma.

BRAF mutations can be seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma and it's histopathology showing branched papillae with orphan Annie eye nuclei is shown below.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: An intern commits a negligent act in the hospital. You as his senior doctor will be held responsible for the negligent act as the intern is working under you. This is explained by _____.
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by vicarious liability.

Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allows it to continue without objection.

When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses his control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control. This is known as borrowed servant doctrine.

Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care from the patient's part or from the attendant. This act, along with the negligent act of the doctor has contributed to the injury. If there was no contributory negligence, the injury would not have occurred. The doctor's negligence is not the direct cause of the injury. Eg. refusal to take required treatment, getting discharged against the doctor's advice, etc.

Res ipsa loquitur in Latin means "the thing speaks for itself". If an untoward result happened that is thought to be due to deviation from the normal standards of care, or negligence, then the doctor should admit the problem. The doctor should take the responsibility to explain the issue to the patient and their family, and solve the problem by either initiating treatment or transferring care. There should be no charge for additional care or for further procedures.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female patient underwent breast conservation surgery due to a 4x4 cm lump in her right breast. The histopathology report showed high nuclear grade DCIS with necrosis and 5 mm margin clearance. Immunohistochemistry showed ER-negativity. What is the next best step in management?

DCIS- Ductal carcinoma-in-situ

ER- Estrogen receptor
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management would be total mastectomy according to the Van Nuys prognostic index (VNPI).

Van Nuys prognostic score for this patient is:

  • The size of the tumor is given as 4x4 cm (score 2)
  • 5 mm margin clearance (score 2)
  • High nuclear grade with necrosis (score 3) 
  • The age of the patient is 38 years (score 3)

The total score is 10 and hence total mastectomy is indicated after breast conservation surgery.

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is more common than lobular carcinoma in-situ. Histologically, DCIS is due to the proliferation of epithelium that lines the minor ducts resulting in papillary growth within the duct lumina. There are 4 morphological types of DCIS namely papillary, cribriform, solid, and comedo. 

Van Nuys system classifies ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) based on the following parameters:

  • Patient's age
  • Tumor size
  • Margin width
  • Nuclear grade 
  • Presence of microcalcification

In 2002, the Van Nuys Prognostic index was modified as the University of Southern California/VNPI (USC/VNPI).

Scoring system for USC/VNPI:

Parameters Score 1 Score 2 Score 3
Size(mm) ≤15 16-40 ≥41
Margin(mm) ≥10 1 - 9 <1
Class low or intermediate nuclear grade without necrosis low or intermediate nuclear grade with necrosis

high nuclear grade with or without necrosis.
Age(years >60 40-60 <40

The current recommendations for the management of DCIS according to this index are:

  • Excision alone for scores 4, 5, and 6
  • Excision plus radiotherapy for scores 7, 8, and 9
  • Mastectomy for scores 10, 11, and 12

Note: The type of microcalcification seen on imaging determines the nuclear grade of DCIS. While the linear branching type of microcalcification is associated with high nuclear grade, the fine granular type is associated with low nuclear grade.

Other options:

Option B: Adjuvant chemotherapy is not indicated in the treatment of DCIS

Option C: Adjuvant radiotherapy is indicated in DCIS patients with Van Nuys prognostic scores 7, 8, and 9.

Option D: Adjuvant tamoxifen therapy is indicated in DCIS patients with estrogen receptor-positive.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the marked vessel?
questions.solution:
The marked vessel is the basilar artery. The posterior inferior cerebellar artery is not a branch of the basilar artery. It is a branch of the vertebral artery.

Branches of the basilar artery are:

  • Numerous pontine branches
  • Labyrinthine artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior cerebral artery

Note: Labyrinthine artery is usually a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, but variations in its origin include basilar artery, superior cerebellar artery and occasionally posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text: You are at a health camp screening children in a community for malnutrition. According to the new WHO growth standards, the cut-off value of mid-upper arm circumference to define severe acute malnutrition is _______.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of fever, fatigue, and weight loss for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor and bruising on his lower limbs and abdomen. Bone marrow aspirate is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: DIC is a dreaded complication of this disease
All-trans retinoic acid is used in treatment
Blast count of 10% is required to establish a diagnosis

questions.solution:
The bone marrow aspirate findings in this patient show myeloblasts containing Auer rods (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions) are suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML/ APL) variant of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). A blast count of ≥ 20% is required to make a diagnosis.

The below image shows Auer rods. 

The patient presents with fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On examination, findings consistent with anemia (pallor) and thrombocytopenia (easy bruising) are seen. This is due to the accelerated destruction of RBC and platelet precursors in the bone marrow. 

APL is associated with aberrant translocations between chromosomes, one of which is t(15;17). This translocation results in the formation of a fused gene with components of promyelocytic leukemia (PML) from chromosome 15 and retinoic acid receptor alpha (Rar-alpha) from chromosome 17. This fused gene codes for a chimeric protein (PML-Rar-alpha) that blocks promyelocyte differentiation.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a complication of APL. Symptoms can range from minimal bleeding to significant hemorrhage (gastrointestinal, intrapulmonary, intracranial). This is thought to be secondary to the Auer rods and primary granules present in promyelocytes. They activate the coagulation cascade and cause consumptive coagulopathy responsible for the bleeding manifestations. 

All-trans-retinoic acid (tretinoin, ATRA) increases the concentrations of the Rar-alpha which in turn relieves this block and facilitates further differentiation. 

The mainstay of treatment includes induction (cytarabine + anthracycline) and post-remission chemotherapy.

questions.text: A young woman was diagnosed with a structural uterine abnormality by hysterosalpingography. Which two anomalies cannot be easily differentiated from each other by this investigation?
questions.solution:
Septate and bicornuate uterus are the two anomalies that cannot be easily differentiated from each other by hysterosalpingography (HSG). HSG provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour. 

A bicornuate uterus is characterized by two separate endometrial cavities, that may communicate with each other and a single uterine cervix. It is caused by the incomplete fusion of the müllerian ducts. Failure of fusion may extend to the cervix, resulting in a complete bicornuate uterus, or may be partial, causing a milder abnormality. 

On HSG, the bicornuate uterus is seen as widely diverging horns with an intercornual angle >105 degrees. However, MR imaging is necessary to define the external or fundal contour.

A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity. It is caused by the failure of the medial segments of the müllerian ducts to regress, creating a permanent septum within the uterine cavity. The septum can project minimally from the fundus or can extend completely to the cervical os. 

On HSG, the intercornual angle is <75 degrees (as shown in the image below). 

Unfortunately, the majority of angles of divergence between the horns fall between 75 and 105 degrees leading to overlapping between the two anomalies on HSG.

Transvaginal 3D ultrasonography (3D TV USG) is the best investigation to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus and is recommended for the assessment of patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Pelvic MRI without contrast also provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV US is not possible as in the case of virgins.

Other options:

Uterus Didelphys: A didelphic uterus is characterized by two separate uterine horns, each with an endometrial cavity and cervix. It results from the failure of the fusion of the paired müllerian ducts.

Arcuate uterus: It is characterised by minimal fundal cavity indentation or a slight midline septum within a broad fundus.

questions.text: The endoscopy and biopsy of a patient with progressive dysphagia and weight loss suggested a diagnosis of esophageal carcinoma. This patient's barium swallow is most likely to show _____.
questions.solution:
The barium swallow of a patient with esophageal carcinoma is likely to show irregular strictures with shouldered margins.

Esophageal carcinoma is a disease of mid-late adulthood and typically presents with dysphagia. Squamous cell carcinoma usually affects the upper 2/3rd of the esophagus and adenocarcinoma affects the lower 1/3rd. Tobacco and alcohol are the main etiological factors.

Endoscopy is the first-line investigation, and a biopsy is required for diagnosis. Other investigations are usually done to define the extent of local or distant spread. On barium swallow, strictures with an ulcerated, irregular mucosa and shouldered margins are seen, as shown in the image below.

 

Contrast-enhanced CT from neck to pelvis is done to identify hematogenous metastases. Only patients who are suitable for curative therapies should be staged. Locoregional staging is done using endoscopic ultrasonography and laparoscopy.

Other options:

Option B: The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm. 

Option C: A smooth stricture without shouldering in the lower esophagus is suggestive of benign peptic stricture, seen in reflux esophagitis.

Option D: A thin submucosal web that encircles the lumen at the squamocolumnar junction refers to Schatzki’s ring.
 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese male patient was started on prazosin for the treatment of hypertension. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this drug?

choices.text: It is highly bound to plasma proteins
It has selective α2 receptor blocking property
First dose has the risk of producing syncopal attack

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about the drug prazosin is that it has a selective α2 receptor blocking property. It is a typical α1 receptor antagonist and has little or no effect on the α2 receptor.

Prazosin acts by blocking the alpha-1 receptors in the arterioles and veins, thereby decreasing peripheral vascular resistance. It reduces the cardiac preload. Thus the norepinephrine release from sympathetic nerve endings in the heart is avoided. This accounts for the relative absence of reflex tachycardia.

It is highly bound to plasma proteins and metabolized in the liver and excreted primarily in bile. Its duration of action lasts about 6-7 hours in the treatment of hypertension.

It is used in the treatment of Raynaud's disease, hypertension, and congestive heart failure. It also has an off-label use in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It has a beneficial effect on the lipid profile of this patient as it decreases LDL and triglyceride levels as well as increases HDL levels.

The first dose is usually given at bedtime so that the patient will remain recumbent for at least several hours to reduce the risk of syncopal reactions and orthostatic hypotension. This is called the first dose phenomenon.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: Which of the following functions is regulated by the lateral superior hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
The lateral superior hypothalamus regulates thirst. It is also an integrating area for hunger. 

Other options:

Option A: Body rhythm control is integrated by suprachiasmatic nuclei of the hypothalamus.

Option B: Sexual behavior is integrated by the anterior ventral hypothalamus.

Option D: Temperature regulation is integrated by the anterior and posterior hypothalamus.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of epistaxis while playing cricket. There is no history of trauma or fall. He also gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding and earache. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

The above clinical scenario of an adolescent boy of age 12 years presenting with recurrent spontaneous epistaxis, earache, and contrast-enhanced CT scan showing anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/ Holman Miller sign) is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves

Diagnosis: It is mostly clinical. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.

Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system also. 

Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgery is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

Other options:

Option A- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor closely associated with Epstein-Barr virus infection. They are predominantly seen in the fifth to the seventh decade of life. Cervical lymph nodes involvement, nasal obstruction, epistaxis, nasal discharge, conductive hearing loss with serous otitis media, squint, and diplopia due to involvement of the cranial nerves III, IV, and VI.

Trotter's triad, characterized by conductive deafness, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis may be seen. 

Option C- Inverted papilloma/ Ringertz tumor/ Schneiderian papilloma is the tumor of the non-olfactory mucosa and paranasal sinuses. It is caused due to human papillomavirus. It is more commonly seen in males of the age group 40-70 years. Patients will almost always present with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. Orbital invasion can result in proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation. CT scan shows the location and extent of the tumor.

Below is the CT image showing an inverted papilloma. 

Option D- Blow-out fracture is the isolated fracture of the floor of the orbit. The clinical features include ecchymosis of the lid, conjunctiva, enophthalmos, diplopia, and hypoesthesia of the cheek and upper lip. Water's view on radiograph and CT scan shows a characteristic convex opacity bulging into the antrum from above known as the tear-drop sign.

Below is the CT image showing the tear-drop sign of blow-out fracture.

questions.text: In a 48-year-old patient with type-2 diabetes mellitus, fundus examination revealed the presence of hard exudates. In which of the below-marked layers of the retina would you appreciate this finding?
questions.solution:
Hard exudates mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer - layer 3. It can be identified as it lies between two nuclear layers. 

In the given image:

  1. Inner plexiform layer
  2. Inner nuclear layer
  3. Outer plexiform layer
  4. Outer nuclear layer

Hard exudates are the extravasation of fluid rich in fibrin and protein around the area of leaking micro-aneurysms. They mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer. They appear as well-defined small, bright yellow deposits with crenated margins.

Common eye findings seen in retinal vascular diseases and the layers involved:

Microaneurysms are seen as a result of focal dilation of the capillary wall following loss of pericytes. They are commonly observed in the inner nuclear layer. 

Soft exudates, also known as ‘cotton wool spots’, occur due to the accumulation of cellular debris that occurs as a result of ischemia. They are seen in the nerve fiber layer. They appear as ill-defined, cloud-like soft aggregates with feathery margins.

Flame hemorrhages are due to the rupture of blood vessels in the nerve fiber layer. They assume flame shape because of the collection of blood in between the parallel running nerve fibers.

Drusen are extracellular deposits seen in age-related macular degeneration. These are located in the interface between the retinal pigmentary epithelium and Bruch membrane.

  4. Inner plexiform layer

  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer

  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: On noticing the capnography of a patient showing the tracing below, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing. Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted CO2 absorbent or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: Exhaled dead space gas 
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau, indicating the transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau that corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveoli. 
  • Following phase III, there is a sharp inspiratory downstroke. It is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Other options:

Option A- Esophageal intubation shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by the absence of carbon dioxide. Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero. 

Option B- In the capnograph of a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, there is no plateau before the next inspiration with an increased up-slope of phase III. Seen in bronchospasm (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), or if the endotracheal tube or breathing circuit is partially obstructed. 

Option D- A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity suggests malignant hyperthermia. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is admitted with symptoms of ear pain and ear discharge, which was not responsive to topical measures. He also complained of pain while chewing. A swab was taken and cultured; the isolate was a strict aerobe, and the catalase test was positive. What is the likely etiology of his infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the laboratory findings are suggestive of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive catalase reaction. Enterococcus, Lactobacillus, and Streptococcus are catalase negative.

Catalase test: When a microbial colony is placed in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the catalase enzyme degrades H2O2 into H2O and O2. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles. People with chronic granulomatous disease have recurrent attacks of infection with catalase-positive organisms.

Catalase positive organisms:

  • Staphylococcus
  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio    
  • Nocardia
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella   
  • Enterobacteriaceae   
  • Listeria
  • Neisseria meningitidis   
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • Yersinia
  • Brucella

Catalase negative organisms:

  • Streptococci
  • Enterococci
  • Lactobacillus

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/ pyoverdin. Other pigments these organisms produce include pyorubin (red) and pyomelanin (brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/ Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric, sepsis, and invasive disease
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pseudomonas is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by producing diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses, such as burns, predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Pseudomonas is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas. Biochemical tests, such as arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction, make species identification possible. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green-colored colonies are shown in the image below.

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

Oxidase positive organisms:

  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella
  • Neisseria
  • Brucella
  • Moraxella
  • Burkholderia
